verses.text: After the death of Joshua, the Israelites asked the LORD, "Who should go up first for us against the Canaanites to attack them?"
verses.comment: Retains the Hebrew query format; 'asked the LORD' reflects the inquiry, sometimes understood as consulting via Urim/Thummim or priest.

verses.text: The LORD said, "Judah will go up. I have handed the land over to him."
verses.comment: Translation uses 'handed the land over' as close to original Hebrew 'given into his hand.'

verses.text: Judah said to his brother Simeon, "Come with me into my allotted territory, so we can fight against the Canaanites. Then I will go with you into your territory." So Simeon went with him.
verses.comment: Maintains tribal language. 'Allotted territory' for 'lot.'

verses.text: When Judah went up, the LORD gave the Canaanites and Perizzites into their hands, and they struck down ten thousand men at Bezek.
verses.comment: Includes Perizzites as in original; mentions location Bezek explicitly.

verses.text: They found Adoni-Bezek at Bezek and fought against him, defeating the Canaanites and Perizzites.
verses.comment: Adoni-Bezek is translated as a name, meaning 'lord of Bezek.'

verses.text: Adoni-Bezek fled, but they pursued him and caught him, and cut off his thumbs and big toes.
verses.comment: Literal rendering of the disfigurement, as in Hebrew.

verses.text: Adoni-Bezek said, "Seventy kings with their thumbs and big toes cut off used to pick up scraps under my table. As I have done, so God has repaid me." Then they brought him to Jerusalem, and he died there.
verses.comment: Preserves original meaning and quotation.

verses.text: The men of Judah fought against Jerusalem and captured it, then struck it with the sword and set the city on fire.
verses.comment: Direct translation, matches Hebrew idiom 'struck with the edge of the sword.'

verses.text: Afterward, the men of Judah went down to fight against the Canaanites who lived in the hill country, the Negev, and the lowland.
verses.comment: Uses geographic designations as in original; 'lowland' for 'Shephelah.'

verses.text: Judah went against the Canaanites living in Hebron (Hebron was formerly called Kiriath-Arba) and defeated Sheshai, Ahiman, and Talmai.
verses.comment: Includes bracketed old city name as note.

verses.text: From there, they went against the inhabitants of Debir (Debir was formerly called Kiriath-Sepher).
verses.comment: Preserves old and new city names.

verses.text: Caleb said, "I will give my daughter Achsah as a wife to whoever attacks and captures Kiriath-Sepher."
verses.comment: Keeps offer and conditions verbatim.

verses.text: Othniel son of Kenaz, Caleb’s younger brother, captured it, so Caleb gave him his daughter Achsah as a wife.
verses.comment: ‘Younger brother’ clarifies original familial relation.

verses.text: When she arrived, she persuaded Othniel to ask her father for a field. She dismounted from her donkey, and Caleb said to her, "What do you want?"
verses.comment: Literal rendering of 'dismounted'; preserves conversational dialogue.

verses.text: She said to him, "Give me a blessing. You have given me land in the Negev; give me springs of water." So Caleb gave her the upper springs and the lower springs.
verses.comment: Retains request for ‘blessing’ and geography.

verses.text: The descendants of Moses’s father-in-law, the Kenite, went up from the city of palms with the people of Judah into the wilderness of Judah, which is in the Negev near Arad; they lived among the people.
verses.comment: ‘City of palms’ refers to Jericho as in original.

verses.text: Judah went with his brother Simeon, and they attacked the Canaanites living in Zephath and completely destroyed the city. So it was called Hormah.
verses.comment: 'Completely destroyed' reflects Hebrew 'herem' (devoted to destruction).

verses.text: Judah captured Gaza with its territory, Ashkelon with its territory, and Ekron with its territory.
verses.comment: Translates 'territory' for 'border.'

verses.text: The LORD was with Judah, and he took possession of the hill country, but he could not drive out the people living in the valleys because they had iron chariots.
verses.comment: Maintains cause of inability: 'iron chariots.'

verses.text: They gave Hebron to Caleb, as Moses had said, and he drove out from there the three sons of Anak.
verses.comment: 'Three sons of Anak' as per original, some manuscripts name them.

verses.text: However, the people of Benjamin did not drive out the Jebusites living in Jerusalem, so the Jebusites live with the people of Benjamin in Jerusalem to this day.
verses.comment: ‘To this day’ as common Hebrew idiom for ongoing circumstance.

verses.text: The house of Joseph also went up against Bethel, and the LORD was with them.
verses.comment: ‘House of Joseph’ means tribes of Ephraim and Manasseh.

verses.text: The house of Joseph spied out Bethel (Bethel was formerly called Luz).
verses.comment: Retains parenthetical place-name clarification.

verses.text: The spies saw a man coming out of the city and said to him, "Please show us the way into the city, and we will treat you kindly."
verses.comment: 'Treat you kindly' translates Hebrew hesed as steadfast kindness.

verses.text: He showed them the way into the city, and they struck the city with the sword, but they let the man and all his family go free.
verses.comment: Consistent use of 'struck with the sword;' releases the man's family.

verses.text: Then the man went to the land of the Hittites and built a city, which he named Luz; that is its name to this day.
verses.comment: Preserves 'to this day' idiom; 'land of the Hittites' as original designation.

verses.text: Manasseh did not drive out the people of Beth-shean, Taanach, Dor, Ibleam, or Megiddo and their surrounding towns; so the Canaanites continued to live in that land.
verses.comment: Direct translation of place names; 'surrounding towns' for 'villages.'

verses.text: When Israel grew strong, they put the Canaanites to forced labor, but did not fully drive them out.
verses.comment: 'Forced labor' for Hebrew 'tributary/servitude.'

verses.text: Ephraim also did not drive out the Canaanites living in Gezer, so the Canaanites have lived among them in Gezer.
verses.comment: Simple, literal rendering with localities as in Hebrew.

verses.text: Zebulun did not drive out the inhabitants of Kitron or Nahalol, so the Canaanites lived among them, but became forced laborers.
verses.comment: ‘Forced laborers’ as in previous verses for consistency.

verses.text: Asher did not drive out the people of Acco, Sidon, Ahlab, Achzib, Helbah, Aphik, or Rehob.
verses.comment: Cities are listed unchanged for accuracy.

verses.text: So the Asherites lived among the Canaanites, the inhabitants of the land, because they did not drive them out.
verses.comment: ‘Lived among’ is a literal rendering.

verses.text: Naphtali did not drive out the people living in Beth-shemesh or Beth-anath, but lived among the Canaanites, the inhabitants of the land. The people of Beth-shemesh and Beth-anath became forced laborers for them.
verses.comment: Maintains original structure and forced labor reference.

verses.text: The Amorites drove the people of Dan back into the hill country. They did not allow them to come down into the valley.
verses.comment: Preserves original sense of Amorite dominance over Dan.

verses.text: The Amorites continued to live in Mount Heres, in Aijalon, and in Shaalbim; but the hand of the house of Joseph prevailed, and they became forced laborers.
verses.comment: ‘Forced laborers’; ‘prevailed’ matches Hebrew idiom ‘was heavy.’

verses.text: The border of the Amorites was from the ascent of Akrabbim, from Sela upward.
verses.comment: ‘Ascent of Akrabbim’ and ‘Sela’ are geographical markers unchanged.
